Patch Set 13: Code-Review+2
Change has been successfully merged

I don't think this is right. The instance ID is unique to the TID for the issued command for the period over which that command is valid (i.e. before timeout). However, we're not validating the TID of the received message matches the TID to which we sent the request. I think that's the primary problem here. We shouldn't need to be matching on the type and command.

Note that we probably need to base this fix on top of Rashmica's fix for the `pldm_transport_recv_msg()` API:

https://gerrit.openbmc.org/c/openbmc/libpldm/+/65337

That way we can learn the TID for the comparison we require here.

Below one example which the instanceID can be equal.
1. When `pldmtool platform GetPDR -a` command is called. pldmtool open the mctp socket, to start getting PDRs. -> pldmtool owes one socket instance.

2. At time t (ms) pldmtool send GetPDR to get the first PDRs and get the response -> it has PDRs. Right after that it calls DBus interface to get next instanceId to get next PDR.

3. At time t + 1 (ms) pldmd call GetSensorReading to get the sensor value. pldmd continue call GetSensorReading after each 2 ms.

4. from time t + 1 to t + 1 + 32*2 pldmd sent 32 GetSensorReading request and received 32 response for that command. InstanceID of those command will occupy the range [0:31] of instance ID.

5. At time t + 1 + 32*2 + 1, pldmtool get new InstanceID from D-Bus interface, it sends the GetPDR request. Because the response messages is broadcast between the mctp socket instances. The socket instance of pldmtool will feed the pldmtool with the response of GetSensorReading commands from pldmd. pldmd is free these responses but the pldmtool is not free them.

6. One of instanceId of GetSensorReading response equal with the instance id in GetPDRs request.

Okay. Several things:

1. Your scenario outlined above is in terms of the behaviour of the mctp-demux-daemon with its broadcasts. AF_MCTP sockets do not behave this way, therefore any work-arounds like you're proposing should go in the mctp-demux transport implementation, and not in generic code like you have here.

2. If pldmtool successfully allocates an instance ID at step 5, then it must be the case that there's no in-flight request associated with that instance ID. As such, it must also be the case that draining the socket on entry to `pldm_transport_mctp_demux_recv()` is enough - any message that previously used that instance ID must already be enqueued in the socket, and can be removed prior to invoking `pldm_transport_send_msg()` to remove the ambiguity.

I just updates the code to free the unexpected message before send the TX request. Because number of the response can bigger than PLDM_TID_MAX so I used `do ... while (rc == PLDM_SUCCESS)`.
Let me know your idea.
We can't have an infinite loop. My upper bound of 32 was wrong as you point out, but `32 * 256` should work?

> but if polling is not supported then the above for will always run 32 256 times

I assume you meant `32 * 256 (= 8196)` there, not `32256`. A bound of 8196 iterations is *much* better than non-termination.

But setting that calculation aside, the main concern is around when polling is not supported.

What we need to be clear about here is the split between *consumers* of libpldm and *implementers* of libpldm. A *consumer* of libpldm is an actor who merely uses libpldm's existing APIs and does not add or modify them. By contrast, an *implementer* of libpldm is an actor who expands or modifies libpldm's APIs.

The available transport implementations provided by libpldm are a closed set. Anyone adding a new transport implementation to libpldm is necessarily an *implementer* of libpldm by the definition above. Your concern about the case where polling is not supported would be a problem if the path could be triggered by a *consumer* of libpldm (through a consumer-supplied callback, for example), but that is not the case. Both transport implementations currently provided by libpldm have functional `poll()` implementations. An implementer introducing a new transport must test that the library's behaviours are sensible for their new transport. At the point of that testing we may have to change the implementation of `pldm_transport_send_recv()` to accommodate any unique behaviours of the new transport implementation. But that's fine, because they're just implementation details, and are not changes in behaviour of a public API.

> C) Can you think again about original solution 'add checking type/command' after those discussion?
>
> - It is simple.
> - No definite case because we have time out 4800ms
> - If we use above solutions , when we polling the existing response before sending request more response from pldmd can come -> take more time.

I still prefer we do not do this. This test is not required by the specification and IMO it muddies the waters of the implementation. Draining the socket prior to send deals with some implementation warts that are beyond the specification and its implementation matches that concern.

Regarding the timeouts and taking more time, no matter which approach we take we still have to process the the same number of messages from the socket in a given scenario. The point of difference is *where* we discard them in time and in the implementation. If anything, I think my proposal has a positive impact on potential timeouts because we discard any messages in the socket prior to sending the request (starting the timer), which means that the timeout period more accurately reflects the intent of the spec.

What are your thoughts?

> > but if polling is not supported then the above for will always run 32 256 times
> 
> I assume you meant `32 * 256 (= 8196)` there, not `32256`. A bound of 8196 iterations is *much* better than non-termination.

I missed `*` in my previous comment. I mean "but if polling is not supported then the above for will always run 32*256 times" or `8196 times` as your correction.

> 
> But setting that calculation aside, the main concern is around when polling is not supported.
> 
> What we need to be clear about here is the split between *consumers* of libpldm and *implementers* of libpldm. A *consumer* of libpldm is an actor who merely uses libpldm's existing APIs and does not add or modify them. By contrast, an *implementer* of libpldm is an actor who expands or modifies libpldm's APIs.
> 
> The available transport implementations provided by libpldm are a closed set. Anyone adding a new transport implementation to libpldm is necessarily an *implementer* of libpldm by the definition above. Your concern about the case where polling is not supported would be a problem if the path could be triggered by a *consumer* of libpldm (through a consumer-supplied callback, for example), but that is not the case. Both transport implementations currently provided by libpldm have functional `poll()` implementations. An implementer introducing a new transport must test that the library's behaviours are sensible for their new transport. At the point of that testing we may have to change the implementation of `pldm_transport_send_recv()` to accommodate any unique behaviours of the new transport implementation. But that's fine, because they're just implementation details, and are not changes in behaviour of a public API.

So as you said the poll will always be supported. That mean at some point the `poll()` will return time out.

> 
> > C) Can you think again about original solution 'add checking type/command' after those discussion?
> >
> > - It is simple.
> > - No definite case because we have time out 4800ms
> > - If we use above solutions , when we polling the existing response before sending request more response from pldmd can come -> take more time.
> 
> I still prefer we do not do this. This test is not required by the specification and IMO it muddies the waters of the implementation. Draining the socket prior to send deals with some implementation warts that are beyond the specification and its implementation matches that concern.
> 
> Regarding the timeouts and taking more time, no matter which approach we take we still have to process the the same number of messages from the socket in a given scenario. The point of difference is *where* we discard them in time and in the implementation. If anything, I think my proposal has a positive impact on potential timeouts because we discard any messages in the socket prior to sending the request (starting the timer), which means that the timeout period more accurately reflects the intent of the spec.
> 
> What are your thoughts?

I knew that adding there is no requirement to check type and index command in the specs. Anyways, I agree that we should follow the spec. So let forget about option C.

> IMO, there is the point which pldm_transport_poll(transport, 0) will return 0 (time out) so both codes will be exited at some points (no infinity loop).

I don't think we can state that in general. We can't be putting constraints, beyond the PLDM specification, on the behaviour of processes that are running concurrent to ours. Applications running concurrent to ours can continue sending messages as much as they wish (especially currently, given our violation of the spec with the lack of per-TID queuing), which we will keep receiving due to the behaviour of mctp-demux-daemon.

> Because there is no guarantee that there are only 8196 messages which are not consumed by pldmtool

If you're going to state that then you're acknowledging that the do-while loop doesn't really have a bound. We need a bound so execution doesn't just disappear into libpldm and never return to the application (this is also true of your proposal in option C). If we hit the 8196 limit we should return an error, as there isn't really any other sensible bound that I can think of. We need to choose an error which is appropriate to return.

How about adding new return `PLDM_REQUESTER_SOCKET_BUSY = -13,`to `pldm_requester_error_codes`?
```
typedef enum pldm_requester_error_codes {
	PLDM_REQUESTER_SUCCESS = 0,
	PLDM_REQUESTER_OPEN_FAIL = -1,
	PLDM_REQUESTER_NOT_PLDM_MSG = -2,
	PLDM_REQUESTER_NOT_RESP_MSG = -3,
	PLDM_REQUESTER_NOT_REQ_MSG = -4,
	PLDM_REQUESTER_RESP_MSG_TOO_SMALL = -5,
	PLDM_REQUESTER_INSTANCE_ID_MISMATCH = -6,
	PLDM_REQUESTER_SEND_FAIL = -7,
	PLDM_REQUESTER_RECV_FAIL = -8,
	PLDM_REQUESTER_INVALID_RECV_LEN = -9,
	PLDM_REQUESTER_SETUP_FAIL = -10,
	PLDM_REQUESTER_INVALID_SETUP = -11,
	PLDM_REQUESTER_POLL_FAIL = -12,
	PLDM_REQUESTER_SOCKET_BUSY = -13,
} pldm_requester_rc_t;
```
yeah, though maybe `s/SOCKET/TRANSPORT/` (`PLDM_REQUESTER_TRANSPORT_BUSY`) so we're not leaking implementation details?
Ok, Let use `PLDM_REQUESTER_TRANSPORT_BUSY`.
Updated.
Not PLDM message and the un-expected endpoint PLDM messages should be different as my opinion.
Done
When the poll() is time out, the method will return zero. Use PLDM_REQUESTER_POLL_TIME_OUT error to different with PLDM_REQUESTER_SUCCESS when time out happens.

Please rebase on top of this:

https://gerrit.openbmc.org/c/openbmc/libpldm/+/64812
Done
The while will continue until there is no more message. The poll returns error or time out.
See my reply on line 51.
Done
We need an upper bound here. We need to avoid infinite loops in a library. I was wrong about my bound of 32 before, but really it's `32 * 256` for the reason you mentioned previously.
Please see my feedback for line 196.
LGTM
